body.p: You can use this process when you want to remove one or more nodes permanently from the Swift system. This process has three phases:

ul.li: Removing the node's drives from the rings - move data off the node and store it on the remaining nodes.
Disabling Swift on the node - prevent the node from participating in the Swift system.
Removing the node from the input model - the node is removed completely from the system.

section.title: To Remove a Node's Drive from the Rings
section.p: To remove a node's drives from the rings, change the role of the server that is being removed so that it uses that disk model that does not include Swift drives. Then a new ring is built and deployed. The new rings will not contain the node's drives.

ol.li:
Edit the definition of the server (usually in the data/servers.yml file). For example, if the entry for the server looks like:- name: SWOBJ-DISKS - id: swobj4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.5 role: SWOBJ-ROLE server-group: RACK3 ...
Change the role to a new value, for example, SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE:- name: SWOBJ-DISKS - id: swobj4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.5 role: SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE server-group: RACK3 ...

Edit the server-roles definition (usually in the data/server_roles.yml file) and add the SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE role. Keep the interface model of the original SWOBJ-ROLE, but change the disk model to SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS:- name: SWOBJ-ROLE interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ disk-model: SWOBJ-DISKS
- name: SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ disk-model: SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS

Add the new role to the server-role attribute of either the cluster or resources item (depending on context). For example, for a Swift object server, the original server-role attribute looks like: resources: - name: swobj ... server-role: SWOBJ-ROLE ...
Change this to a list containing the original SWOBJ-ROLE and the new SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE as follows: resources: - name: swobj ... server-role: - SWOBJ-ROLE - SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE ...

Create a SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS disk model by editing the file containing the SWOBJ-DISKS disk model (usually the data/swobj_disks.yml file) and adding an entry for SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS. Make a copy of the SWOBJ-DISKS disk model, but change the consumer field from swift to swift-draining. For example:disk-models: - name: SWOBJ-DISKS volume-groups: - name: hlm-vg ... consumer: name: os device-groups: - name: swiftobj devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd consumer: name: swift attrs: rings: - object-0
- name: SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS volume-groups: - name: hlm-vg ... consumer: name: os device-groups: - name: swiftobj devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd consumer: name: swift-draining attrs: rings: - object-0Before you run any playbooks, remember that you need to export the encryption key in the following environment variable: export HOS_USER_PASSWORD_ENCRYPT_KEY=<encryption key>. For more information, see .
Commit the changes to Git:cd ~/helion git commit -a -m "<commit message>"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Create a deployment directory:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Run the swift-deploy.yml playbook. Do not limit this process to just the node (helion-cp1-swobj4) that you are draining:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-deploy.yml

Wait until replication has finished. For more information, see .
At this stage, all data has been moved from helion-cp1-swobj4 and replicated on the remaining nodes. Now, you can proceed to the next phase.

title.b: To Disable Swift on a Node

section.p: The node is still running Swift services. It is still part of the input model and is fully configured so that you can log in and perform the other operations.

To disable the node, use the following steps. In this example, swobj4 is the node being removed from Swift.
Stop Swift services on the node using the swift-stop.yml playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-stop.yml --limit <hostname>
The following example uses the swift-stop.yml playbook to stop Swift services on helion-cp1-swobj0004:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-stop.yml --limit helion-cp1-swobj0004When using the --limit argument, you must specify the full hostname (for example: helion-cp1-swobj0004) or use the wild card * (for example: *swobj4*).
Remove the configuration files. This process assumes you are logged onto the Deployer:ssh helion-cp1-swobj4-mgmt sudo rm -R /etc/swiftDo not run any other playbooks until you have finished the process described in To Remove a Node from the Input Model. Otherwise, these playbooks may recreate /etc/swift and restart Swift on swobj4. If you accidentally run a playbook, simply repeat the process in To Disable Swift on a Node.

title.b: To Remove a Node from the Input Model

section.p:
Use the following steps to remove a node.
Edit the servers list (usually in data/servers.yml file). Remove the entry for the node (swobj4 in this example).
If this was a SWPAC node, reduce the member-count attribute by 1 in the control-planes definition (usually in the data/control_plane.yml file). For SWOBJ nodes, no such action is needed.
Commit the changes to Git:cd ~helion git commit -a -m "<commit message>"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Create a deployment directory:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Remove the node from Cobbler:sudo cobbler system remove --name=swobj4 ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml
If the node was a SWPAC node, run the hlm-deploy.yml playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml
Wait until replication has finished. For more details, see .
You may need to continue to rebalance the rings. For instructions, see Final Rebalance Phase at .
